questions.text: Which of the following is the constituent of the marked area in the electron microscopic picture of muscle?
questions.solution:
Alpha actinin is the constituent of the marked area.

The image depicts sarcomere and the arrow points towards Z-line. Alpha actinin binds actin to Z-lines.

The orderly arrangement of actin, myosin, and related proteins that produces this pattern. The area between two Z-lines is called sarcomere.


The thick filaments, which are about twice the diameter of the thin filaments, are made up of myosin; the thin filaments are made up of actin, tropomyosin, and troponin.  The thick filaments are lined up to form the A bands, whereas the array of thin filaments extends out of the A band and into the less dense staining I bands.


The lighter H bands in the center of the A bands are the regions where, when the muscle is relaxed, the thin filaments do not overlap the thick filaments.  The Z lines allow for anchoring of the thin filaments. Actinin, titin and desmin are additional structural proteins.


Titin connects Z-lines to the M line and provides the scaffolding to the sarcomere.  Desmin adds structure to Z-lines by connecting Z-line to plasma membrane.


Note: Some sources say that even titin is a component of Z-disc so if alpha actinin is not given in the options titin is the second best answer.

questions.text: Identify the test shown below.
questions.solution:
The above image shows tonometry.

This is a dynamic contour tonometer (Pascal).

Intraocular pressure (IOP) readings are not affected by central corneal thickness.

Pascal is the tonometer of choice for post LASIK corneas.

questions.text: A 54 year old came to casualty with history of massive hemoptypsis. His routine investigation chest X-ray was normal. Which of the following you will not do to prevent hemoptypsis?
questions.solution:
Procoagulant drugs like vasopressin are indicated only if:

  • There is an abnormal coagulation profile.
  • No contraindications to the drug are present.

Massive hemoptysis is generally defined as expectoration of over 600 mL of blood within a 24-h period.

Treatment priorities in the management of massive hemoptysis:

  • Achieve respiratory stabilization and prevent asphyxiation.
  • Localize the bleeding site.
    • Bronchoscopy: flexible / rigid
  • Control the hemorrhage.
    • Endobronchially with laser or bronchial occlusion
    • Endovascularly with bronchial and/or pulmonary artery embolization
    • Surgically with resection of the involved lobe
  • Determine the cause.
  • Definitively prevent recurrence.

questions.text: Which of the following suggests storage of drugs in tissue?
questions.solution:
Storage of drug in tissue suggests large volume distribution.

Drugs with small volume of distribution are confined to vascular component.

Drugs with large volume of distribution are in compartments like adipose tissue, muscle, bone.

Volume of distribution depends on:

  • Lipid solubility
  • pKa value of a drug
  • Degree of plasma protein binding
  • presence of tissue-specific transporters
  • differences in regional blood flow.

Volume (V) = Dose administered I.V. / Plasma concentration

e.g., when 1000mg of drug is injected I.V. and plasma concentration of drug is 50mg/L,

  • V=1000/50
  • V=20L

questions.text: A 32 year old female nearing her due date has been admitted following regular contractions. The resident doctor did an examination and told the intern that the head is at +1 station. What does the exact position of head?

choices.text: High up in the false pelvis

questions.solution:
The station is just below the ischial spine.


Station of the head is in relation to ischial spines as spines are the most prominent bony projections felt on internal examination.


The level of ischial spines is the halfway between the pelvic inlet and outlet. This level is known as station zero (0).


The levels above and below the spines are divided into fifths to represent centimeters. The station is said to be “O” if the presenting part is at the level of the spines. The station is stated in minus figures, if it is above the spines (–1 cm, –2 cm, –3 cm, –4 cm and –5 cm) and in plus figures if it is below the spines (+1 cm, +2 cm, +3 cm, +4 cm and +5 cm).

Stations of the presenting part

questions.text: Which of the following site does the restriction enzyme act when RFLP is used in-order to identify the five different species of staphylococci in a surgical ICU?
questions.solution:
Restriction endonuclease enzymes act at specific palindromic sequences that create DNA fragments of different lengths. By analyzing the fragments, specific species of bacteria can be identified. Option B is the only palindromic sequence here, hence it is the answer.

RFLP is a restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis technique that involves cutting a particular region of DNA with known variability, with restriction enzymes, then separating the DNA fragments by agarose gel electrophoresis and determining the number of fragments and relative sizes. 

Cleavage of a sample of DNA with a restriction enzyme produces a characteristic set of smaller DNA fragments. Deviations in the normal product pattern, produce RFLPs that occur if a mutation renders a restriction site unrecognizable and alternatively, generates a new recognition site.

questions.text: The image below shows the insertion of transversus abdominis muscle. Identify the conjoint tendon:
questions.solution:
The structure marked C is the conjoint tendon.

The conjoint tendon is formed from the lower fibers of the internal oblique and the lower part of the aponeurosis of transversus abdominis. It is attached the pubic crest and extends to a variable extent along the pectineal line.

Transversus Abdominis muscle:

  • Origin: Internal surface of 7th-12th costal cartilages, thoracolumbar fascia, iliac crest, connective tissue deep to lateral third of inguinal ligament.
  • Insertion: Linea Alba with aponeurosis of internal oblique, pubic crest, and pecten pubis via the conjoint tendon.

Other options:

A: Lumbar fascia
B: Transversus abdominis
D: Inguinal ligament

questions.text: Identify the egg in the picture given below
questions.solution:
The egg in the given picture indicates hookworm egg.

Eggs of both Ancylostoma Duodenale (old world hookworm) and Necator Americanus(new world hookworm) are identical.

The eggs of hookworm are :

  • Oval or elliptical
  • Colorless,
  • Not bile stained,
  • With a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane
  • Thin shell
  • Segmented ovum - 4 to 8 blastomeres
  • There is clear space between segmented ovum and egg shell.
  • Eggs float in saturated salt solution.

Humans are infected when filariform larvae in moist soil penetrate the skin.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in low insulin-glucagon ratio ________.
questions.solution:
Low-insulin/glucagon ratio indicates low insulin and high glucagon levels, which are observed in the fasting state. In the fasting state, all of the above processes (i.e., glycogen breakdown, ketogenesis, and gluconeogenesis) occur, but not glycogen storage.

 

Metabolic process

Fasting state/ low insulin-glucagon ratio

Fed state/ high insulin-glucagon ratio

Gluconeogenesis

Increased

Decreased

Glycogenolysis

Increased

Decreased

Ketogenesis

Increased

Decreased

Glycogen storage

Decreased

Increased

questions.text: March fracture is seen following stress in ____ of second metatarsal
questions.solution:
This question is about stress fracture of the 2nd metatarsal which is called March fracture.
This is a controversial question. We have chosen Neck as the right answer, since only one option can be chosen.

What various sources say:

  • Campbell orthopedics 13/e says, " patients often note the gradual onset of pain directly over the second metatarsal neck region."
  • Uptodate says, " A disproportionate number of stress fractures occur in the second metatarsal shaft, especially at the neck."
  • Grays anatomy 41/e says, "  Metatarsals are miniature long bones and have a shaft, proximal base and distal head."

This question is controversial because according to Gray’s anatomy 41/e, the metatarsal bones do not have a neck. But when we have a look at uptodate, things start to get clear. Neck is part of the shaft and is the most common site for fracture. This is also confirmed by Campbell orthopedics. As this is an orthopedics question the best answer is neck of the metatarsal. The best answer to the question is in the following order:

Neck of the shaft > Neck > Shaft

March fracture is the neck of the shaft fracture of 2nd and 3rd metatarsal resulting from long, continued or often repeated stress like prolonged walking or running in people not accustomed to it. Thus it may occur in army recruits freshly committed to marching hence the name March Fracture.

It heals spontaneously , so its treatment is symptomatic.

questions.text: Pancreatic cancer has the highest association with _______.
questions.solution:
Pancreatic cancer has the highest association with Peutz–Jeghers syndrome (~132-fold increased risk).

Hereditary risk factors:

Syndrome Germ-line mutation

Estimated increased risk (fold) of
Peutz–Jeghers syndrome STKII (LKB1) ~132 
Hereditary pancreatitis  PRSS 1/SPINK1 ~ 53
Cystic fibrosis CFTR  ~ 30
FAMMM syndrome p16/CDKN2A  ~13-38 
Hereditary breast and ovarian cancer BRCA 2  ~3.5-10 
HNPCC /Lynch syndrome MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2  ~9-30

FAMMM: Familial atypical multiple mole melanoma

HNPCC: Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer 

This MCQ has been updated to reflect the information provided in Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition - Germ-line Mutations, Their Familial Cancer Syndrome, and Fold Risk of Pancreatic Cancer.

questions.text: On thyroid function test analysis, TSH value was much higher than normal with a low free T4. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An elevated TSH value with low free T4 is suggestive of primary hypothyroidism (Option D).

Option A: In subclinical hypothyroidism, free T4 levels remain normal despite elevated TSH.

Option B: TSH is low in hyperthyroidism.

Option C: The diagnosis of secondary hypothyroidism is made along with a deficiency of other pituitary hormones. TSH levels may be low, normal, or slightly increased. The elevation in TSH levels can be attributed to the secretion of immunoreactive but biologically inactive forms of TSH. To confirm the diagnosis, it is essential to detect a low level of unbound T4.

The diagnostic approach to hypothyroidism is given in the flowchart below:

Related Pearl: Causes of Hypothyroidism

 

Primary

(Low T3, T4 → Raised TSH levels)

Secondary

(Low TSH levels → Low T3, T4)

Tertiary

(Low TRH → Low TSH → Low T3,T4)

Hashimoto’s thyroiditis

RAI therapy for Grave’s disease

Post thyroidectomy

Excessive iodine intake - Wolff Chiakoff effect

Subacute thyroiditis

Medications: Antithyroid drugs, lithium

Iodine deficiency, dyshormonogenesis

Pituitary tumour

Pituitary resection or ablation

Hypothalamic insufficiency

Resistance to thyroid hormone

questions.text: A young patient came with complaints of acute abdominal pain on and off and tingling sensation of limbs and at times weakness of limbs. She had a history of eating paint from the wall of newly built house. Which of the following enzyme defect will be the cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of lead poisoning in children is seen due to lead paint and according to the history, it is evident that the case is of lead poisoning and the enzyme defect seen is ALA dehydratase.

Lead is toxic because it can substitute for calcium in many fundamental cellular processes. Lead can cross red blood cell membranes as well as the blood–brain barrier and enter the neuroglia cells which support brain function.

Heme biosynthesis is initiated by the condensation of succinyl–CoA and glycine in a reaction catalyzed by mitochondrial ALA Synthase.

Condensation of two molecules of ALA, catalyzed by cytosolic ALA dehydratase forms porphobilinogen which is essential in heme synthesis.

Fatal dose: 20g of lead acetate

Fatal period: 1 to 2 days.

Symptoms:

Abdominal pain, headache, anemia, irritability and, in severe cases, seizures, coma and death.

Diagnosis

X-rays will expose dense lines in the long bones of children and red cells undergo a change known as basophilic stippling, where blue-staining remnants of destroyed DNA are seen lining the margins of the red cells.

The main tool for diagnosis is measurement of the blood lead level.

Treatment depends on the blood level and is designed to remove the lead from the body by chelation therapy.

questions.text: The definition of fever of unknown origin (FUO) includes all of the following, except:

choices.text: Undiagnosed after one week of investigation
Immuno compromised status should be ruled out
Fever persisting for more than 3 weeks

questions.solution:
The current definition of fever of unknown origin (FUO) does not include undiagnosed after one week of investigation. The criterion "diagnosis uncertain, after 1 week of evaluation" which was previously a part of the definition has been removed.

FUO is currently defined as:

  • Fever ≥38.3°C (≥101°F) on at least two occasions 
  • Duration of ≥3 weeks
  • No known immunocompromised state
  • Diagnosis is uncertain after thorough history-taking, physical examination, and obligatory investigations.

Inflammation of Unknown Origin (IUO) is closely related to FUO. It has the same definition, except for the body temperature criterion. IUO is characterized by elevated inflammatory parameters (such as CRP or ESR) on multiple occasions for at least three weeks in an immunocompetent patient with normal body temperature. The causes and workups for IUO are similar to those for FUO.

questions.text: While volunteering in an orphanage that takes care of disabled kids, you notice the typical hand-knee gait of polio in a child. He walks by putting his right hand on his right lower thigh while stepping forward. Which of the following muscle weakness is responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
Polio commonly affects the quadriceps, and weakness of the quadriceps leads to the buckling (bending) of the knee while walking or bearing weight on the leg. So, in order to walk, the person has to prevent the buckling of the knee by supporting with the hand, producing a hand-knee gait.

Examination findings in paralytic polio:

A. In the early stage

  • Asymmetric motor paralysis - involvement of affected muscles is haphazard. No associated sensory loss.
  • Commonly affects the lower limbs
  • Most common muscle affected - Quadriceps, although it is most often partially paralyzed
  • Most common muscle to undergo complete paralysis - Tibialis anterior
  • The most affected muscle in the hand - Opponens pollicis
  • Bulbar/bulbospinal polio - It is a rare but life-threatening disease affecting the motor neurons of the medulla and resulting in the involvement of the respiratory and cardiovascular centers, which may cause death.

B. In the late-stage

  • Weakness, wasting, and deformity of the limbs
  • At the hip-flexion-abduction-external rotation
  • At the knee, flexion deformity is common; in severe cases, there is triple deformity: flexion, posterior subluxation, and external rotation
  • At the foot, the commonest deformity is equino-varus. Other deformities - equinovalgus, calcaneo-valgus, and calcaneo-varus
  • In the upper limb: affects the shoulder and elbow, hand muscles are spared.

questions.text: A 5 year old with gradually progressive hoarseness of voice over three months and respiratory distress for 2 weeks. Diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests that the child is suffering from Respiratory papillomatosis.

Respiratory papillomatosis (juvenile papillomatosis )

  • It is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children.
  • It is caused by HPV 6 and 11. 
  • Involves supraglottic and glottic regions of larynx .
  • C/F
    • Age 3–5 years
    • Hoarseness or aphonia
    • Respiratory difficulty
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy. 
  • Treatment consists of microlaryngoscopy and CO2 laser Excision.

Other options:

  • Options A) Croup (acute laryngotracheobronchitis) and D) Acute epiglottitis are acute conditions and therefore ruled out.
  • Option C) Vocal Nodule: They appear symmetrically on the free edge of vocal cord, at the junction of anterior one-third, with the posterior two thirds due to trauma. Present only with hoarseness.

questions.text: What does the red cell distribution width (RDW) deal with ?
questions.solution:
RDW deal with anisocytosis.

When the red cells vary greatly in size, anisocytosis is said to be present.

The electronic cell counter provides an independent assessment of variability in red cell size. It measures the range of red cell volumes and reports the results as “red cell distribution width” (RDW). This value is calculated from the MCV; thus, cell width is not being measured but cell volume is.
In the presence of morphologic anisocytosis, RDW (normally 11–14%) increases to 15–18%.
In patients with microcytic anaemia, the differential diagnosis is generally between iron deficiency and thalassemia. In thalassemia, the small red cells are generally of uniform size with a normal small RDW. In iron deficiency, the size variability and the RDW are large.

questions.text: Which is the most appropriate treatment for the patient suffering from below condition
questions.solution:
Ventricular tachycardia (VT) is three or more consecutive beats at a rate faster than 100 beats/min.

Two features suggestive of VT in this patient are:

  • Tall left rabbit ear in V1 – Brugada's sign
  • Absolutely positive QRS complexes in aVR – Vereckei's sign positive

Treatment

  • Amiodarone for stable patients
  • DC Cardioversion for unstable patients.

questions.text: A 36 year old male came with complaints of ascending weakness in both lower limbs and upper body. There was no history of trauma. Which of the following investigations is done in the evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes a patient with ascending paralysis. Among the given options, Serum potassium (Option A) is tested as disturbances in serum potassium levels (hypokalemia or hyperkalemia) present with ascending muscle weakness.

Option B: Hypomagnesemia can cause tetany. Hypermagnesemia can cause generalized weakness and paralysis. However, serum potassium is a better answer as disturbances in potassium levels are more likely to cause paralysis.

Option C: Alteration in serum sodium levels does not cause muscular paralysis.

Option D : Hypocalcemia presents with paresthesia, tetany, seizures and prolonged QT interval. Hypercalcemia presents with other clinical features like fatigue, depression, mental confusion, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, constipation, reversible renal tubular defects, increased urine output, short QT interval in the electrocardiogram, and, in some patients, cardiac arrhythmias.

questions.text: A 25 year old female came to opd 1 year after delivery. She was treated for iron deficiency anemia while pregnant. Now she was pale and her Hb was 5% and reticulocyte count was 9%. Her corrected retic count is: (Take normal Hb as 15g/dl)
questions.solution:
Corrected Reticulocyte is calculated as= (Actual hb/Normal hb) x Reticulocyte %

According to values given in this question,

Corrected reticulocyte count=5 x 9/15 = 3%.

Note: Normal Hb is taken as 15g/dl

questions.text: An 60 year old male presented with history of intractable diarrhea. Based on the histological image shown below which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The most appropriate diagnosis is multiple myeloma. 

The image shows Russell bodies which are eosinophilic, large, homogeneous immunoglobulin-containing inclusions usually found in a plasma cell undergoing excessive synthesis of immunoglobulins; the Russell body is characteristic of the distended endoplamic reticulum.

Globular inclusions are Russell bodies (if cytoplasmic) and Dutcher bodies (if nuclear).

In Renal biopsy, the arrows show the presence of proteinaceous casts (Bence-Jones proteins) in the tubules.

Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell neoplasm commonly associated with lytic bone lesions, hypercalcemia, renal failure and acquired immune abnormalities.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman was brought to the casualty ward with a history of road traffic accident (RTA) and head trauma.  Her eye opens to pain, moans, can localize limb towards the pain stimulus on the left hand and away from the pain stimulus on the right hand and both the legs in extended posture. Calculate her GCS.
questions.solution:
The GCS (Glasgow Coma Scale) of this patient is E2V2M5, which comes to a total score of 9.
E2-Eye opens to pain
V2-Moans
M5-Localizes to pain on the left hand (the score represents the best performance elicited, which would be localizing towards the pain stimulus)

Revised Glasgow coma scale for head injury:

Minimum GCS is 3, maximum GCS is 15.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: Which of the following movements is being tested in the picture given below?
questions.solution:
External rotation of hip is being tested in the given image.

Rotatory movements of the hip joint can be measured with the knee flexed or extended. However, more precise measurements are obtained when the rotation is tested with the flexed knee. The procedure involves the following steps.

  • The patient is made to lie supine.
  • The examiner holds the knee with one hand and ankle with the other hand.
  • The knee and hip are flexed to 90 degrees.
  • Rotation movement is produced at the hip joint by stabilising the knee and moving the leg as the lever.
  • If the hip is rotated such that the leg moves medially, external rotation of the hip occurs.
  • If the hip is rotated such that the leg moves laterally, internal rotation of the hip occurs.
